articles.title: Scenic highway in Florida to get extra protection from hurricanes, erosion
articles.author: Andrew Wulfeck
articles.summary: The Florida Department of Transportation is building a buried seawall along State Road A1A to protect it from hurricanes, nor'easters and other erosion events. The project is costing more than $100 million. The buried seawalls are being constructed in limited areas of Flagler and Volusia counties, which have seen repeated storm damage in recent years.

articles.title: Mass. psychologist on the impact climate change has on mental health
articles.author: Rhondella Richardson
articles.summary: Some experts say climate change is making it harder for people to "keep their cool" and affecting their mental health. Dr. James McKowen is a psychologist and co-chair of the Climate and Mental Health Initiative at Mass. General Hospital. NewsCenter 5 spoke to him to learn more about the impact of climate change.

articles.title: Greek Seas Warming Faster Than Usual, New Data Shows
articles.author: Greek Reporter
articles.summary: Satellite data shows sea surface temperatures across Greece in early June have ranged from 20-22 degrees Celsius (68-71 degrees Fahrenheit). This is notably above average for this time of the year, which means there is a cumulative phenomenon at work, says the satellite data.

articles.title: The Sun's Fury Is Making SpaceX Satellites Plummet From The Sky
articles.author: Michelle Starr
articles.summary: The number of SpaceX's Starlink satellites falling from the sky as a direct result of increased solar activity between 2020 and 2024 shows a clear link with the Sun. The number of satellites in low-Earth orbit and solar activity are the highest ever observed in human history. The work of Denny Oliveira and his colleagues may help design strategies to mitigate the orbital drag induced by solar activity.

articles.title: Forecasting hope: Climate action for a more resilient Cook Islands
articles.author: Cook Islands News
articles.summary: Cook Islanders have a close connection to their land and feel a sense of stewardship to protect it against the changing climate. Extreme coastal hazards are increasing, including rising sea levels, tropical cyclones and changing rainfall patterns. Cook Islanders are isolated and vulnerable as small island communities in a vast ocean.
